creator: macke@yar.nu
text:
The latest 1.7 does not address this (according to the release notes), and I
could find no enhancement request discussing it either.

My simple proposal is:

Allow the user to set a custom handler for resolving properties (with the option
to handle unset properties as errors), similar to setting build listeners.

We've been running with a modified Ant 1.6.2 for some time that simply throws an
exception if a non-set property is accessed (when another propery is set, namely
ant.disallow_unset_properties). It works really nice for us and has helped
finding quite a few bugs (that's why we added it in the first place), but a more
general solution would be to provide various property-policies. 

This was discussed quickly on the ant-user-list and the response was 'why not?'.
So I'll try to get some time to write a small patch on this. Will post it here
later, unless someone has a strong opinion otherwise.

Not sure how familiar you are with Ant's codebase.  Actually, though, there
already exists the concept of the PropertyHelper chain, which AFAIK could be
used in the way you suggest.  In current and recent versions of Ant you can
install a custom PropertyHelper using a custom task, or a <script>.  What is
missing is a better way to install a custom PropertyHelper.
creator: mbenson@apache.org

text:
Getting better at that. *browse* :) Yes, using a custom PropertyHelper should work.

I have no problem using a <script>, however I can't find out where to replace
the current PropertyHelper instance (which PropertyHelper's setNext() indicates
should be possible). I can move that query to the mail-list, if you'd like.
